item.description:
Climate Game is a game which when played with strategy, negotiation and diplomacy, challenges its players to save the world from imminent destruction. With everyone’s effort and awareness, the emission of carbonic gas can be reduced before it is too late.

This game is both one of competition and of cooperation. It promotes competition because the player who emits no carbonic gas at all is the winner. But, integrated work of all the other participants is essential in order not to exceed the gas limits of the greenhouse effect that the planet can put up with. If this limit is exceeded, the Earth’s temperature will have risen to a level where human life is not possible and everyone dies/loses.

Therefore, participants must have a good degree of knowledge regarding gas emission and the greenhouse effect and also be very good at negotiating and formulating strategies.

Eco Planet is a board game aimed at environment preservation awareness. The players have a race to see who gets to Eco Planet first, which is an ecologically tolerable place. In order to get there, the players must know the causes, effects, consequences and solutions for the planet’s degradation.

There are five theme groups: air, water, soil, global warming and environmental awareness. When a player gets the correct answers to the questions asked about the theme he/she is on, he/she moves forward on the board.

Eco Planet may be distributed to employees, clients, suppliers, partners and to the community for the promotion of the planet preservation idea. This game can and must be taken home and played with the whole family and with friends.

http://www.games4b.com/ecoplanet.php

It is a card game.
The aim of this game is to identify and eliminate your ennemies.

At the beginning, the four players receive one card. It will determine which team you are part of (Blue Ying Yang or Red Ying Yang). Players should keep theirs secret.

At your turn, you had to play a card :

- hit someone (10 pts, 20 pts, 30 pts)
- heal someone
- protect someone
- identify someone

You can't heal or protect yourself.
When someone has been hit for an amount of more than 101 pts, he must reveal his identity and he is dead.

O Quem Sabe PartiCIPA é o jogo que fala sobre a CIPA Comissão Interna de Prevenção de Acidentes. Essa norma tem como objetivo a prevenção de acidentes e doenças decorrentes do trabalho, de modo a tornar compatível permanentemente o trabalho com a preservação da vida e a promoção da saúde do trabalhador.

No jogo os participantes concorrem para ver quem será o primeiro a atravessar a trilha da CIPA. Para avançar no tabuleiro é necessário acertar as perguntas que falam dos vários temas: principais normas regulamentadoras, equipamentos de proteção, mapa de risco, classe de fogo, universo CIPA e áreas da fábrica. Durante o jogo, os papeis desempenhados pelos participantes, que são os mesmos na CIPA de verdade, vão se alternando, o que aumenta a emoção do jogo.

O Quem Sabe PartiCIPA é um jogo que deve ser distribuído para os cipeiros e para os funcionários das empresas como forma de conscientização para os perigos e os riscos do ambiente de trabalho, assim como para a educação do uso dos equipamentos de segurança individual ou coletiva. É um jogo que pode ser distribuído como brinde nas SIPATs (Semana Interna de Prevenção de Acidentes do Trabalho), em eleições da CIPA, ou mesmo em aniversários e comemorações relacionadas às metas de segurança da empresa.

Assim, o Quem Sabe PartiCIPA é o jogo ideal para a promoção da cultura da segurança do trabalho. Lembre-se que acidentes podem ser prevenidos pelo seu conhecimento e atitude! A segurança de todos depende de você e do treinamento da sua equipe. Bom jogo.


O Quem Sabe PartiCIPA is the game that talks about the CIPA Committee for the Prevention of Accidents. This standard aims at preventing accidents and illnesses resulting from work in order to make it compatible to work permanently with the preservation of life and the promotion of occupational health.

In the game the participants compete to see who will be the first to cross the path of CIPA. To advance on the board, you must set the questions that speak of various subjects: major regulatory standards, protective equipment, risk map, class of fire, the universe and CIPA areas of the factory. During the game, the roles played by participants, which are the same in real CIPA, will be switching, which increases the excitement of the game.

O Quem Sabe PartiCIPA is a game that should be distributed to the accident prevention commission and employees of companies such as awareness of the dangers and risks of the workplace, as well as for the education of use of safety equipment individually or collectively. It is a game that can be distributed as a gift in SIPATs (Week for the Prevention of Accidents at Work), in elections of CIPA, or even birthdays and celebrations related to the security goals of the company.

Thus, knowing O Quem Sabe PartiCIPA is the ideal game for the promotion of culture of safety. Remember that accidents can be prevented by their knowledge and attitude! The safety of all depends on you and training your team. Good game.

Introduction:

Ri+Val (Ritual) is a game of strategy based on the Books of Rituals. 
The books are collections of rituals, where each page is an ancient manuscript with which you can tackle your opponent. 
In Ritual every player embodies the spirit of an Immortal Sorcerer who must demonstrate his magical abilities and strategic skills. 
Each book is protected by 5 seals: once they are destroyed the Sorcerer can take possession of the opponent's Book: 
the ultimate goal is to control as many books as possible becoming the most powerful sorcerer in History!

Setting:
Millenias ago, an ancient powerfull civilazation was at its most high evolution point. All of its society was based on the magic and spiritual power of Nature. There were five Guilds,
Earth, Fire, Water, Air and the Guil of Destiny which rulled them all with justice and equity.
One day Evok, the demon spirit of the Abyss, escaped from his century long imprisonment. He promised revenge over the ones who chained him for so long in Darkness.
Gathering all sorts of evil souls and demons he attacked with fury the Capital of that ancient world.
The flames reached the sky, floods destroyed the land and everything seeemed near to an end...
The most powerfull Sorcerers then united their powers for the final battle against Evok: after an epical fight the evil spirit was resealed in his Jail forever.
Unfortunatly, that ancient world was destined to extinction, therefore the Sorcers wrote down on books all their knowledge and magic power.
Now these books have returned to chose the future of this world: who will be the most powerfull Sorcerer?!

General Game Rules:
Every player has a book which contains 33 Rituals
Evey book is "protected" by 5 Seals (this can be read as every player has 5 life points)
The Rituals are devided in Curses, Blessings and Summonings
which use Runes to be cast in to play.
They also have Element Points and Seal points which show the
power of every single Ritual.

Every turn you have 5 Runes to use.
The Turn is divided into 
1-Casting Phase: 
put into play the Rituals

2-Combat Phase
fighting phase

3-Closing Phase
resolution of combat

This is the general description of the game's rules,
shortly it will be available on the website.

name.value: Basic Action Super Heroes! Sci-Fi Edition

item.description:
This is a Sci-Fi themed variant of the original Basic Action Super Heroes! game.

The basic mechanic is rolling 2d6 and multiplying the result by the appropriate stat (Brawn, Agility, or Mind) plus any applicable modifiers and beating a target number. Simple and easy.

Characters are built on points. While there are plenty of options here, it won't take you hours to build a character and you could jot all relevant stats down on a 3x5 index card.

This version includes guides for creating alien races. There are also rules for starship combat. Scenarios range from Victorian Steampunky Sci-Fi to Sci-Fi Fantasy to Post Apocolyptic genre.

This newspaper-themed board game was based on 1931 movie "Five Star Final". The game includes a large (30" x 17") and heavy board, five player tokens, 40 Service Tokens, a deck of yellow Assignment Cards, and a deck of white News Cards.

Players take Assignment Cards from the Editor that show events underway around the board. They then choose how to travel there: by foot, bus, elevated, taxi or subway. By foot is slowest but reaches everywhere; subway is fastest but can mean an additional walk to many locations.

To complete an assignment, reporters first must arrive on the spot by exact roll of either two dice or one of the two. If they fail to land on the space two turns in a row, they have missed the story and must head back to the office. However, if they stroll back, they get a chance to draw an Assignment card on any other Assignment location on which they land, getting partial or full credit for that story instead.

Players who do land on their Assignment locations must then try to draw a News Card that matches their assignments, drawing twice a turn until they do. When they do draw the right match, they normally get one Service Token, but none if sent to Rewrite, and two if labelled Front Page. Then they head back to get another assignment. First player to get five Service Tokens wins.

From the back of the box:

Conrad, the notorious colour sheep, is back in action! He eagerly dips his brush alternately into the red, the yellow, the blue, and the green paint pot: Conrad paints everything he has seen on his last trip – and that is quite a lot! Each of you gets three picture cards. Try and move Conrad to the paint pot cards and discard your card of the same colour. Be the first to discard all your cards and win the game!

name.value: Piratas aritméticos: El juego de cartas
Les Pirates Mathématiciens: Le jeu de cartes
I pirati del conto: Il gioco di carte

item.description:
The wild number-pirates once again set off on treasure hunt: Capt. Mathematikus and his parrot Lora sail the Seven Seas. “Treasure island on starboard!“, Lora suddenly caws. Which number treasure will they find today? All players calculate at the same time. Each card displays four arithmetic problems. But only one goes with the operators on the dices. The first player to provide the correct solution receives the card as their reward. Winner is the first to collect five cards.

A pirate-worthy card game for 2 – 4 number pirates

The powerful witch Gundula charmed seven princes. To releases them from the spell, players have to prove their own magical powers and brew a miraculous potion. The princes will be released as soon as the great potion is finished. To mix the elixir and collect prince cards you have to add always two ingredients in the exact order. In the end, you piece your prince cards together and count the points your prince scores. The larger the prince, the more points he scores!

A bewitched card game for 2 – 4 bright junior witches

name.value: Sword of Fire: the battle of Lutter

item.description:
After having passed most of the summer season waiting for event, Christian of Denmark decided to stir himself up and join the other part of his army to combat Tilly, left a little unmanned after having lost several detachments to guard conquered cities. His movements where to slow, and when the two armies joined battle, Tilly was probably a little superior to his opponent. Christian was unable to avoid the clash, and he suffered a defeat.

Each combat unit represents from 250 to 1500 soldiers, and it is rated, from left to right, for combat morale and movement. Each infantry strength point is around 150 men, each cavalry strength point around 80 men. Each leader is rated for Command (indicating how many activation chits that leader has) and Movement.

Each hex is about 75 meters.
Each turn is half on hour.

Contains:
6 page rules
11x17" map (in 2 8.5x11" parts)
1 player aid
216 counters and markers

link.value: Battles of the Thirty Years War 1642 - 1651

item.description:
(from Ad on CSW:)

This is an operational level game, for two players, of the battles that took place in January and February 1944 near the small Russian town of Korsun.

Units are battalions and regiments for the Germans and regiments/brigades and divisions for the Soviets. 
Map scale is 3.2 Kms/hex and each turns represents two days.

Battle for Korsun comes with a full colour 32" x 20" map in 4 sections, 297 mounted color counters, rule book and charts in a ziplock bag.

A game for 2 or 3 players, played with 36 dice per player. Each player tries to score higher than their opponents in rows and columns of a 6x6 grid they fill in with dice.

Each player will fill in his grid die after die, but all players will be using the same die value on a given turn.

In the end, the player with the most high scoring lines wins the game.

item.description:
This is it, pilot. The ultimate battle.

Your fleet is flying toward the enemy, breaking formation to engage individual ships. Each ship charges toward an enemy sector, raising shields to prevent attacks. You have three classes of ships, and your goal is to destroy enough fighting capacity of the enemy fleet to defeat it.

A Star Fleet Scramble set includes:

- A Star Fleet Scramble flexible A4 board.

- 9 blue acrylic ships: 3 battlecruisers (largest), 3 destroyers (midsized), and 3 corvettes (smallest).

- 9 red acrylic ships: 3 battlecruisers (largest), 3 destroyers (midsized), and 3 corvettes (smallest).

This is the 3rd nestorized Icehouse game.

item.description:
Finnish Civil War, is a simulation game of the civil conflict in Finland in the early months of 1918. The game is for two players, one representing the recently elected government of the recently independent state (the White player) and the other the perhaps-irresistible forces of proletarian revolution (the Red Player).

The game comes in two versions: 
1) a company/battalion scale one which uses a system heavily modified from the designer's previously published games Freikorps, Konarmiya and War Plan Crimson; and 
2) a brigade scale one that uses fewer counters and an even more heavily modified system.

Both versions use the same map (hex grid of southern Finland, at 12 map miles/ 20 km per hex). Special units and chromy bits include: variable-strength Red and White Guard units; Armored Trains; the spring thaw that occurred midway through the war; peace negotiations, German intervention and Russian withdrawal (including the Future Guilt Clause!); General Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim; guerrillas; purges; and the Swedish Talent Agency.

Was available for free download at designer's personal webpage from end of 2009, but in October 2012 the designer concluded an agreement with Compass Games for them to publish this game in Paper Wars magazine. Compass Games has requested that the free version of the game be taken down. Both versions of the game appeared in issue #84 of the magazine, in December 2016.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 7 days
Hex: 12 miles / 20 kilometers
Units: Company to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 17 x 22" full-color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (240 1/2" counters)
One 20-page Finnish Civil War rulebook

Solitaire Suitability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-6 hours

Note: One 6-sided die is needed for play

name.value: Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – The Pacific 1942
Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – El Pacífico, 1942

item.description:
In 1942, the Japanese empire exploded across the Pacific, conquering everything before them. The only large land mass still held by the Allies was Australia, which they desperately needed as a staging area for a planned U.S. led counter-attack. The Japanese knew of the importance of Australia, but lacked the resources to conquer it, so they decided on the next best thing: Isolate Australia from the United States by building an airfield on the island of Guadalcanal, from which planes could disrupt the Allied supply lines.

The United States, ill-prepared as it was for any offensive actions, immediately attacked with the 1st Marine Division under the command of Major General Alexander A. Vandegrift, caught the Japanese by surprise and easily took control of the airfield. The Japanese 17th Army, under the command of Lt. Gen. Harukichi Hyakutake, counterattacked with an ever-increasing number of troops. For the next four months a titanic struggle took place in the air, on land and on sea as the isolated Marines and U.S. Army fought for their lives to hold their tiny perimeter around the airfield against the might of the Japanese Empire.

Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – Pacific Ocean 1942 recreates this struggle on your tabletop and includes gorgeous beach and jungles maps of the South Pacific, amphibious landing craft, the USMC, Japanese Banzai Charges, night combat, and much more.

link.value: Conflict of Heroes: Guadalcanal – U.S. Army

item.description:
Join a team of wild life photographers who are taking a collection of photos overseas to an exhibition. Just as they are about to leave they discover that three of their photos are spoiled. By helping each other asnd using your memory work out which photos are'Behind the Lens', but hurry-the lane leaves when it's full.(From the game box).

Behind the lens features 12 endangered species native to New Zealand and their habitats

Strike it rich with this exciting mining-themed board game!

Gold Mine is a unique tile-laying game in which players build a maze of mine tunnels and control miners that traverse the mine collecting gold nuggets. Players race to be the first to collect enough gold to exit the mine and stake a claim. It may sound easy, but the greedy miners have several tricks up their sleeves in order to gain an advantage—including sneaking through secret passages, fighting for gold, and scaring away other miners with bats.

With a different game board every time, a great balance of luck and strategy, and the addition of optional rules, this game is bound to be a family favorite for years to come!

item.description:
Squiggle Connect is a hilarious drawing game where players compete by changing a squiggly line into a picture. No artistic talent required . . . just your imagination!

It all starts with a roll of the dot cube and then the dots are connected by random lines using the connect cube. Once everyone has their unique squiggly line in front of them, play begins. Players have 60 seconds to transform their wavy and wacky line into a picture. They can be as simple or detailed as they want. When time is up, each player explains their drawing to the other players. This is where you may fall over laughing as you listen to some real nonsense! Once each player has had chance to explain what they drew, voting begins. Each player votes on only one other players drawing using a voting card.

The voting cards offer either a descriptive praise or a nuance of criticism such as "put that in a doggie bag" or "a monkey can do better". Each card also has a point value and players give them to each other based on their picture and description. It’s hysterical!

SQUIGGLE Connect recently won a National Parenting Publications Gold Award!

(from manufacturer's website)

Life has always been hard for the gibs. This sub terrain race always had a soft spot for shiny objects. Now that some gems have shown themselves the gibs have all flocked after them.

This light fast paced strategy game can be played in just a half hour and supports 2-4 players. Be the player that has collected the most gems of a single color.

There is a full page of Variants in the new edition to change up game play.

First edition scoring can still be used but 2nd edition has a new Scoring system to stop people from being able to swing the game to dramatically in a single turn.

Doubloon Dippidy is the game that comes with the "collectible" octopus, Dip. The game is similar to LCR. Players start with 2 coins. Players take turns rolling a pair of dice. Depending one what is rolled, the player may have to give coins to the bank or the player on the left or collect to coins. Play continues until only one player has coins left.

The game brings an Octopus, special dice, 30 plastic doubloons & a drawstring bag.

Sink or Swin is a die game that comes with the collectible Octopi Grippa. In the game players roll dice until either they come up with a clownfish or seahorse, which takes the die out of for the turn, or another face which is worth 1 to 3 points. Players keep rolling until they are happy with results or out of dice to roll.

Bed of Pearls is the game that comes with the collectible Octopi named Pearl. The game is vaguely similar to Yahtzee. Players roll dice trying to get good combination. A player can keep rolling until he is happy with the roll or rolls out.

However when you finish your roll and pass the dice. The next player can decide to roll all dice allowing you to score or try and build on your roll.

User summary...

Advertised as "Everyone's Game". Basically three different version of spin a spinner and lay down a bland chip on a bland board. In 1926 this was considered Entertaining, Fascinating and Thrilling!

Says so right on the box.

User Summary...

Spin a top and wait to see which giggling child's mouth the balls land in to score points. Laugh with your friends and laugh at yourself - Giggles Game of Action!

User Summary...

A children's acting game. Pull a cardboard monkey out of the box, read the action silently to yourself and act out as directed. Either award points for the best acting or use the cards to play charades.

(publisher blurb):
A mouth-watering way to learn fractions! This set of 12 realistic 12" (30. 5cm) pizzas is the "main course" upon which eight different fraction games are based. Includes 12 cardboard pizzas cut into halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths, ninths, twelfths, and sixteenths, plus two spinners and an activity sheet. Comes in a sturdy pizza parlor box! For two to six players.

(from box front):
Pizza Party Includes:
- 2 spinners
- Activity Sheet with 8 Games
- 59 Full-Color Fraction Pizza Pieces

Players Will:
- Identify halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eights, ninths, twelfths, and sixteenths
- Identify fractional parts of the whole
- Match fractional notation to concrete models
- Identify equivalent fractions and fractional parts
- Subtract fractional parts from a whole and other fractions

For 2-6 players
Grades 1-6

(description of the 8 games from the activity sheet):
1. Pizza Cover-Up
Skill/Purpose: Identifying the fractional parts that make up a whole.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to cover a pizza with pizza pieces.

2. Pizza Play-Off
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying the fractional parts that make up a whole.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to complete your pizza, with no overlapping pieces.

3. Pizza Pickup
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most pieces after eight turns.

4. Penny a Pair
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most points after three rounds of play.

5. Fraction Line-Up
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have one pizza piece of each size: 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/6, 1/8, 1/9, 1/12, and 1/16.

6. Pizza Patch
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying fractions that are even parts or multiples of another fraction.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have two pizzas in a winnings pile.

7. Undercover
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the player with the most points after 20 rounds of play.

8. Empty the Pan
Skill/Purpose: Matching fraction numerals with concrete models; identifying equivalent fractions/fractional parts; subtracting fractional parts from a whole/other fractional parts.
Goal: The goal is to be the first player to have no part of a pizza left.

O'penzedor is the first game of young designer Cedric Joint.
The game is about opening doors and facing the magic spells behind it. If you have the right counter-spell among the cards in your hands you succeed and win arcane points; if you lose, you can continue though lose points and you give advantages to your opponents (new counter-spell cards).
Some cards with special power spice up the regular magic spells.
O'penzedor is a very simple and fun card-game with nice artwork from Pierro (Ghost Stories, En Garde, Linq, Mr. Jack).
[user summary of playtesting]

name.value: Armoured Wargaming: A Detailed Guide to Model Tank Warfare

item.description:
User Summary:

Primarily an historical digest of armor unit statistics, the book also contains a dozen pages of rules for 1:300 scale model tank wargaming. Scenarios and mixed- unit rules are, however, left to the reader's imagination.

Rulebook:
You and your companions are a ragtag bunch of zombie-fighting survivors waging a battle against a horde of the dead engulfing the city. Your team will travel across the hotspots, stemming the tide of hungry dead and helping the remaining survivors to safe houses. You must work together, using whatever skills are available to save the survivors before the dead rise up and destroy the city. The clock is ticking as every moment in the hotspot their hunger grows. Will you be able to succeed before the attack of the dead?

item.description:
Miniatures rules for plastic Army Men wargaming. Simple, d6-based rule set that simulates WW2 to modern era combat.

From the publisher:
Plays in 30 minutes or less 
Useable with any cheap figures or carboard "stand-ups" 
No army lists, counters or book keeping required 
Weapons include flame throwers, machine guns, mortars and bazooka 
Rules for infantry, tanks, helicopters, minefields, and mission objectives 
Unit activation based on squad strength / casualties

Join Po & the Martial Arts Masters for an UNO card game showdown! Challenge any opponent to a Kickin' Battle with the exclusive card & rule! And Don't forget to yell UNO when you are about to become the Chosen One!

The swimming ring is placed into the water, players receive all discs of one colour. In his turn a player drops one of his discs into the water, it schwims either showing Nessi or the empty side. Then the next player drops a disc, if it hits another disc in the water, this is turned over. When all discs have been dropped, the player with the most Nessis visisble on his discs wins the game. In a variant one can end the game when the first player has 5 Nessis showing.
Ssssh! With hands and feet only, the players in Pantomime describe the pictures on the cards to other players. Whoever speaks or makes a noise loses.

link.value: HABA Game in a Tin series

item.description:
In Lesehexe, you want to find as many matching word cards as possible. Start by placing a green starter card (A-M) into the card frame, then search for a matching word card. To check whether the cards have been placed together correctly, try to place the witch's shoes into the cutouts. Who can collect the most word cards?

Lesehexe includes seven different game ideas for practicing letters and simple words, providing players with plenty of variety.

User Summary:
An old roll and move race game in german language about Nurburgring circuit.
The players throw the dice to determine the starting positions, then advance their tokens according to the subsequent launch of the dice.
On the track there are points that help competitors to move faster, or force them to lose precious time waiting for a favorable launch.
The first player who crosses the finish line after six turns (but at beginning of the game he may also determine a different number) is the winner.

User summary:
The players in the shoes of Indiana Jones trying to collect treasures found in various parts of the world, moving through cards and dice.
The game map divides the world into 5 zones. The players depart from North America, their base, and move on other continents where they are hidden treasures to find.
On every continent there are 3 decks of cards and the last of each deck is a treasure that can be real or false in 2 cases out of three.
The goal of the game is, therefore, to discard the cards placed over the treasure to get to the bottom of the pile and earn the trophy.
The cards are discarded throwing the dice and passing score on the card in various skills, if it not succeeds, the card remains in place.
The more cards you discard the more your skills will increase.
When discovered 4 treasures will be turned into points and the player with most points is the winner.

item.description:
User summary:
Roll and move race game with cartoon characters...
From back box:
"Everything is ready for departure. Competitors shudder at the wheel of race cars craziest of prehistory.
Here deploy robust Flintmobile , the fast Sabertooth, the reliable Rubblemobile and, finally, the agile Rockasaki.
And now are start!
Along the streets of Bedrock City held the most exhilarating race of prehistory. Vehicles from different performance and unplanned stop decided by your passengers, refueling or police checks, will make the race even more enjoyable. But remember that luck is not enough. A bit of strategy may prove decisive.
Is best a fast vehicle that consumes many gasoline or that slow one but never stop? The choice is yours. So are you ready? The craziest race of prehistory is about to begin. Yabba-dabba-doo!

User summary:
Addition with numbers like Scrabble.
From box:
"I Numeri Incrociati" are for lovers of figures and calculations that are the crossword puzzles for fans of the vocabulary.
The principle is simple: to achieve, adding the chips numbered one or more of the numbers from the cards drawn at random at the beginning of the game.
At the billboard can cross because each successive combinations can be achieved either horizontally or vertically.

User summary:
Roll and move race game of the early '70.
From rules:
Contestants will choose their cars and take the card boxes and card run.
Will proceed in turn by moving their marker on the track, every move you will throw 2 dice and the number obtained will happen what happens on their card race (eg wildfire: stop for 2 shifts, skidding: advance 2 spaces ...).
If the dice roll indicates the stop in the pits the player must stop at the next garage space on the track and throw a dice to see the consequences (eg, oil change: stop a turn; tire change: advance 2 spaces, etc..)
Win the race who will cut the finish line first.
It's possible can make an entire season of 15 Grand Prix.

User summary:
Roll and move race game about Moto GP of early '70.
From rules:
At the game can participate from 2 to 5 competitors.
The entire route is divided into 25 fractions by 10 km each. Players will proceed on the track throwing the dice, whose numbers indicate the gear on the vehicle, 6 indicates a stop (not moving).
Before you start you have put along the track the employees to pit which will, to player who stops in the vicinity, the chances of mechanical failure to his bike.
The "Campionato Mondiale di Motociclismo"will be held in several Grands Prix each of which will be ongoing in the 125cc category (will be held at 1 lap), 350cc (to be played in 2 turns) and 500cc (to be played in 3 rounds).

In Ach Du Lieber Biber, beavers are surfing the waves of the icy river towards the waterfall, but while they do so, they have to beware of the floating junk and other surfers. The player who lets the fewest beavers tip over the waterfall wins the game.

In more detail, the players place the water cylinders on the river and randomly organize the surfing beavers and junk markers on top of them. They take turns rolling a "surfing die" to determine whether they have to progress the water level, with the aid of a wooden lodge across the river, towards the edge of the waterfall.

item.description:
This is a pretty blatant (and surely unlicensed) ripoff of Trivial Pursuit.

Everything in the game revolves around scouting. The categories are "Lord & Lady Baden-Powell", "International", "Events and places", "Swedish history and now", and "Literature and misc". Players roll dice to move pawns around the board and ask questions related to the category-space upon which they land. The goal of the game is to get point-pieces by landing on the prime space for the category and correctly answering a question in that category. The goal is to get point-pieces in all of the categories and then answer a final quesion from a category chosen by the opponents.

A cooperative or competitive fantasy role-playing board game, the goal of which is to bring about or stop the Armageddon that will destroy the kingdom. The alignment of the characters chosen determines if the players will fight for or against the Great Evil that threatens to destroy the land.

Players explore the modular map board, revealing tiles as they go. Gameplay is primarily driven through adventure cards in which monsters are fought, treasure is found, quests are solved, and clues are uncovered that can narrow down the identity of the Great Evil. The climax of the game occurs when the identity of the Great Evil is revealed and the final battle is fought which will determine the fate of the Kingdom.

item.description:
Fibonacci's Trump is a basic trump/trick-taking card game.

Collect tricks through playing cards depending on the color that is led, using the trump color when able. Points are determined by the symbols on the cards: the number of the symbols that is the same as the Symbol Indicator collected determines how many points you are awarded each round.

Scoring uses Fibonacci's numbers... so the more symbols you collect, the better off you are.

First player to 144 wins.

item.description:
From the back of the box:

Nestled deep in the Black Forest of Bavaria lay the town of Shoental. Although the villagers worked hard, the village remained in poverty, because the domination of the dragon Gruenaugen. Gruenaugen demanded half of all goods produced by the village, or the villagers would face destruction from the dragon's wrath. Many a young lad had set forth to slay the dragon, never to return.

The young town miller (der Mueller) spent many hours thinking about the plight of his town. He knew that previous attempts to destroy the dragon by force had been fruitless. He also knew that Gruenaugen loved games, as all dragons feel they are intellectually superior. He invented a game that only the cleverest would win and confronted the dragon with a deal: freedom of the village if der Mueller won, or enslavement of der Mueller if Gruenaugen won. Gruenaugen, feeling he was superior, naturally accepted.

Der Mueller facest the hardest test of his life but overwhelmed the dragon with his strategy and won. Der Mueller returned to the village a hero. Gruenaugen was never seen again.

A strategy game for two players. The object of the game is to capture 5 of your opponent's gems. Each player starts with 8 gems and tries to complete trios to capture theur opponent's gems by placing their gems on the board during phase one, sliding their gems during phase two, and picking up and moving their gems during phase three.

Re-Implements:

Nine Men's Morris

This is a trivia game of men versus women in which all the questions are based around gender and have numerical responses. Each team answers questions about the opposite gender in regards to love, life, work, appearance, etc. Women could be asked: What percent of men report cheating on their taxes? Men could be asked: On average, how many pairs of shoes does a woman own? Teams attempt to place several cards in order from least to greatest based upon their guessed answers. Packaged inside is an electronic card scanner with automatic scoring (no more cheating here) and an adjustable volume. This electronic base communicates with players throughout the game, so there is no need for an instruction booklet.

Rat Zvijezda (Star Wars) is croatian published game which puts the players in the role of Imperator {Emperor Palpatine}, Darth Vader, Han Solo or Luke Skywalker.
Each character controls one of the powers from the last three parts of Star Wars trilogy - Imperial Fleet (Imperator) and Death Star (Vader) vs. Millenium Eagle {Millenium Falcon} (Solo) and Hoth (Luke).

Armies are composed of fighter squadrons, foot soldiers, cannons and famous allies from series. Combat is conducted primarily through series of dogfights and landing and invading opponent bases. Of course, force duels are present as well.

Donuts, chocolate, and chips!

In Snack Factory it’s up to you to keep the world supplied with their favorite snacks. In each round you will need to balance profit and sales while maximizing productivity to stay ahead of the competition.

Think you have what it takes? Reach for a delicious snack and try your hand at running the best snack factory!

Snack Factory incorporates a climbing style card game with clever scoring mechanics to give players interesting and challenging decisions!

(Publisher Blurb)

item.description: It's Monopoly with the theme of the town of Audubon NJ. The game use local stores on the game board.The game was a fundraiser fo the local sports teams, The Green Wave.

In this game two armies clash and the only thing that will discourage them is the fact of losing their king in battle. All the king’s men will fight to death for him, regardless of the fact that even the king is a fierce fighter.
This last battle takes place in a very strange land, long tunnels that are always changing to confuse anyone that wanders in them.

With similar mechanics as in “NiMeMo” you have to move your army around the board and try to eliminate your opponent’s pieces by blocking them.
As soon as you eliminate the other’s king you win.

Dédalo (in Spanish) comes from Daedalus. In Greek mythology Daedalus was a skilful craftsman and artisan. The Labyrinth on Crete was created by him.
So as in this game we have an ever-changing labyrinth I decided to give it Daedalus’ name on his honour.

English rules available.
http://legalalien.sakura.ne.jp/wiki/index.php?Tabletop%20Wargaming/Shinsengumi%20Ikedaya%20Incident%20English%20Rules

On June 8th, 1864, in Kyoto, there was a very famous sword-action between Shinsengumi and Kinnoh-rohshi. Yes, it was Ikedaya.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ikedaya_Incident

It was rumored that the most radical group of Kinnoh-rohshi had planned to kidnap Komei-emperor from Kyoto while they set up fires around Kyoto-city.
Shinsengumi, the patrol group hired by Edo-bakuhu decided to assault the Kinnoh-rohshi's meeting before the final moment. They found the meeting at Ikedaya.

This is a small postcard game. It was distributed on A-game shop's yearend-yearopening campaign between 2009 and 2010.
Basically this game uses the same game engine as 47 Ronin. Each player take action by one of his stack alternatively. Each stack can move and then fight to adjacent enemy stack. This is chess-like puzzle movement. A goes to attack B to open the path. But, the enemy moves C to defend the path just opened. And so on.
Also, if you have issue #1 of Wargame Japanese History, you can use counters from Shinsengumi Chronicle for this game.

Though this is a small game, it is filled with puzzle-like tactics and excitement of swordplay.

updated
This game is reprinted as a second game of Wargame Japanese History #27.

name.value: Wallis's New Game of Universal History and Chronology

item.description:
'Locomotive Game'

This game from 1840 is a reworked issue of the 1814 edition of the game and the central area of the game has been updated to reflect later historical events.

The racing track comprises of 143 circles, starting with Adam & Eve and ending with a railway train.

In the middle of the 1930s, an expedition of treasure hunters crashes its zeppelin in the middle of an unknown and mysterious island where legends tell that several old and powerful civilizations have left many sumptuous treasures.

Each player is one of these brave explorers who joined the expedition with old maps giving clues on where some of these treasures can be found. However, it is clear that the land is barely known and dangerous, so, all explorers decide to travel together, in one solid group by hiring beasts of burden and exotic items in the native villages while trying to avoid the many dangers of the inhospitable land of Isla Dorada...

Which one of these brave explorers will find the most valuable treasures, avoid the numerous curses and accomplish it's rewarding destiny?

In Isla Dorada, players will have to move a unique pawn portraying the expedition of explorers. Each player will collect cards of different kinds (movements, actions, destinations, curses, destinies, bonus or malus cards) and will have to build the best hands turn after turn (time is limited to a certain number of game turns) to be able to chose the expedition destinations in a succession of bids and negotiations. Doing so, the players will try to put their hands on treasures while avoiding their cursed destinations and trying to block other player's objectives.

The very easy rules can be learned in a few minutes whilst the rich and elegant game play assure an always renewed experience.

name.value: Toe-to-Toe Nu'klr Combat with the Rooskies
Toe-to-Toe Nuclear Combat with the Rooskies

item.description:
This is it, Boys, we're going in...

The “Go Code” has been received and the war plan decoded; it is time to turn your B-52 into Soviet air space, and head for your primary target. You’ve got 50,000 lbs. of fuel, two H-bombs, a crew looking to you for leadership, and a mission that your country needs you to fulfill.

Toe-to-Toe Nu’klr Combat with the Rooskies is a fast-playing solitaire game. You decide the payload, pick your targets and must then challenge the Soviet Union's defenses.

SAMs (surface-to-air missiles) and Soviet Air Defense fighter/ interceptors will find you as you cross “The Big Board.” Events will relentlessly dog you and your crew as the fate of America, even the world, rests on your shoulders. A single mission can be accomplished in about 15 minutes, or take an hour for the whole campaign game. Take a darkly humorous trip in a less-than-serious game exploding with atomic fun.

BATTLESSONâ„¢ Game #8.

Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale

item.description:
Microbadges: 


Tattered Flags is a series of Kriegspiel-style historical miniatures/board game depicting battles of the American Civil War (1861-1865). In this first game in the series, each player controls a Union or Confederate force at the Battle of Gettysburg, struggling for The Wheatfield on July 2nd, 1863. Gettysburg: The Wheatfield was carefully crafted to introduce players to system basics of organization, events, maneuver, fire and morale, with future games in this series promising to expand the detail and accuracy of the Tattered Flags system.

Since many players do not have the time, funds or eyesight to paint armies of miniature figures, Tattered Flags comes with colorful cardboard counters, called “Stands” (in the vernacular of miniatures gaming). These games also use a printed battlefield game map in lieu of miniature trees, hills, buildings, etc. Feel free to substitute miniature figures if desired!

There are three scenarios included in Gettysburg: The Wheatfield, each with its own Order of Battle (OOB), Special Rules, Turn Length and Victory Condition. The first scenario is introductory in complexity and is used when someone is first learning and playing the game. The second scenario is the historical scenario depicting the actual fighting that occurred during the afternoon of July 2nd. The final scenario is a dramatic, “what-if” meeting engagement battle.

Game Data:
Complexity: 5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 7 on a 9 scale
Scale: 1 inch = 50 yards; each Stand is approximately 150 men or 3-4 cannon; each turn represents a variable amount of time, perhaps 15 to 20 minutes or so

Game Components:
• One 12 page color rules booklet with lots of illustrated examples
• One 4 page scenarios booklet
• 60 color, die-cut 1" x 1/2" Stands
• 60 color, die-cut 1/2" square markers
• 8 color, die-cut 5/8" x 1.25" Leader pieces
• 1 beautiful, full color game map
• 20 Event cards
• 2 Player Aid sheets
• 1 Game Turn track
• 1 Movement measuring tool
• 1 Combat measuring tool

name.value: Levée en Masse: Les guerres de la Révolution Française, 1789-1802
Levée en Masse: The Wars of the French Revolution, 1789-1802

item.description:
The Wars of the French Revolution, 1789-1802

States of SiegeTM #5

This solitaire game, suitable for group and classroom cooperative game play, tells the story of the French Revolution through its key events and decision points. You must stop the advances of foreign armies and the counter-revolutionary forces within France itself to defend the virtues of Republicanism.

Can you suppress the forces of Monarchy and Despotism to maintain the Republican spirit in France? Can you export the revolution by liberating neighboring states and granting them their liberty? Will you be able to keep order in Paris as it suffers from riot after riot? Enlist today, grab your musket and a banner, and join the Levée en Masse!

Game Data:
Complexity: 3 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit is one Army, each turn represents a variable number of weeks

Game Components:
• One 6-page, color Game Rules booklet
• 12 color, die-cut 3/4” square game pieces
• Five 5/8“ round game markers
• 48 Headline cards (2" x 3")
• One 11” x 17” color game map
• Designers Notes
• Optional Rules

link.value: Victory Point Games States of Siege Series

item.description:
Catchup is a simple abstract game with a devilish dynamic. The goal is to have the largest group of stones on the board when the board is full of stones, but as you get closer to winning, your opponent gets more powerful. Whereas most stone-placement games are about position, Catchup is about timing, position, and the interplay between them.

Definitions:

1. Group – a set of connected, like-colored stones on the board. A single stone is also considered a group.

2. Score - your score is the number of stones contained in your largest group. At the beginning of the game, both players' scores are set to 1

Rules:

1. One player owns the white stones and the other owns the black. White begins by placing 1 stone on any empty space. 

2. From then on, starting with black, players take turns. On your turn, you may place 1 or 2 stones, or up to 3 if your opponent's score increased on their last turn and is, at the beginning of your turn, greater than or equal to your score.

3. After taking your turn, if your score has changed, move your pawn to the corresponding spot on the scoring track.

4. The game ends when the board is full. The player with the largest group wins. If the players’ largest groups are the same size, compare their second-largest groups, and so on, until you come to a pair which aren’t the same size. Whoever owns the larger of the two wins.

item.description:
Topology is an abstract tile placement game. It is played with 52 tiles with double-hex shape. Each of the 2 edges is connected with another edge by a line. There are different combinations of lines, but they never cross.

Before play, one randomly chosen tile is placed in the middle of the table.
Each turn, the players draw 3 tiles and place them on the table adjacent to the tiles already placed. Whenever a ring of lines gets closed, the player who placed the last tile scores points according to the length of the ring.

After all 52 tiles are placed, the player with the highest score is the winner.

AWARDS:

Topology is the 5th winner of the NESTORGAMES continuous abstract game design contest

item.description:
publisher description

This tabletop adventure game is based upon the cult 1960's TV series 'The Prisoner'. The series featured 'Number 6' a former secret agent of the British Government during the Cold War, who is never identified by name. After resigning his position he is abducted and held prisoner in a small, isolated eccentric sea-side resort known only as 'The Village'.

'Card- Board Games' is a new and exciting concept in tabletop adventure games play. From a simple pack of cards you are able to build up a unique playing area from the centre of your dining table. Since the cards are laid strategically then each game you play will be different and pose new challenges for you.

A playing piece and a few counters are all you need to start the game. Its your job to move your playing piece along the paths to the outer limits of the board without other players getting in your way. As the game develops you collect additional cards which will either help you on your way or impede the progress of the other players.

Designer comments:
Cosmic Goldrush is a game where players try to mine for gold and platinum on the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. On the always-moving, always-perilous, always-changing belt you got look after your water supplies, as well as yourself. Get stranded too long on an asteroid and you'll find yourself out of the board, quite a lot of poorer than a turn before.

Mine, trade, buy stuff, bug your friends and visit the infamous Space saloon for more new stuff.

Virus Wars is a two-player ancient board game that simulates an evolution of two colonies of viruses, which are growing and absorbing (zombifying) each other. The exact origin of the game is unknown but it was actively played as a paper-and-pencil game in Saint Petersburg State University in 80s. There were several variants of the game with slightly different rules.

Players must make five steps per turn. Each step is either placing a new virus on the board or "zombifying" one of the enemy viruses. The goal of the game is to leave the opponent without legal moves.

item.description: User summary: One player is the Evil Wizard. The Evil Wizard may arrange the sections of the gameboard, representing rooms and hallways, in any way desired. The Evil Wizard places the Princess in the last room. The player(s) representing the questing party wins the game if the Princess can escape from the Evil Wizard. The Evil Wizard player wins by destroying the questing party.

A game made in England in the 1950's. There is no publisher listed on the game box. It is a very simple roll and move game on a board with a serpentine track that goes from the start (0) to the finish line (100).
 A six is needed to start the race and an exact roll is needed to hit the finish line. There are many penalty spaces on the board that will stop you or move you back. there are some bonus spaces which move you ahead or give you an extra die roll.
 It comes in a simple cardboard box with the 5 sentence rules glued to the inside top cover lid. The tri-fold board is ~ 16" x 10" when unfolded. There are 4 different colored plastic greyhounds for pawns. A small plastic die tumbler and die are also included.

Fabula (previously known as Grimm) is a story-telling game where players must fill in parts of a story. One of them is the teller, who read (or imagine) the beginning of a short tale — his/her current draft. Each other player incarnates a tentative hero (a gnome, a princess, a little boy, etc.) who tries to be the main character of the teller's tale. 3 times during the game, the teller asks the other players how they think things happened at that time of the story. They must choose an item depicted on one of the cards laying at the center of the table and use it to continue the story. Depending on how convincing they are to the teller, and how well they integrated their character and the item to the current twist, they get points in the shape of "quill" markers. Each item can only be used once by any player, who keeps it afterwards, and who puts his/her markers on top of the card.

At the end of the three turns, the two players with the most quill markers are selected to compete in the epilogue. The teller reads (or makes up) an idea of an ending to the story. Now, each finalist in turn has 30 seconds to present a relevant proposal for including his character and both items figured on the two remaining cards on the table into the ending. (A sand timer is included.) Both players have to use the same two objects, but the second one speaking cannot use them in the same way than the first (more or less compensating the fact he had more time to prepare his part).

Eventually, the teller decides which of the two finalists wins, depending on the relevance of their proposals.

The game comes with two proposed variants :
- "Experienced players" : all the players tell the same tale, each one adding an element to the same storyline and bound to continue using the plot of the former speakers.
- "Collective" : there are no quill markers and appraisal given by the teller. Every player takes part in the epilogue, and there's no winner.

The first player who make it through the rotating maze, and with all of his four mouses reaches the tasty cheese in the middle wins the game.

from a merged entry
A clever and fun little game. The maze is a labyrinth with a clear plastic film that you can turn in order to change the maze. Every player has 4 mice each to control and the goal is to get them from their nests to the middle, where the cheese is. The players roll a dice every turn, and the plastic film on top of the maze is moved that many steps, thus changing the layout.

item.description:
(User Summary.)

Gulp! is a simple card game, in the fashion of War. The cards describe a variety of marine life, and list the other cards that can be "eaten". The set of cards form a partial order: there are a few unique different apex predators that are eaten by nothing, and several instances of the Phytoplankton card that can be eaten - directly or indirectly - by all other cards.

Players each draw a card from the top of the deck: if one card eats the other, then the player claims both; if neither eat the other (or, rarely, both eat the other) then each chooses an additional card, with the winner of the next pair taking all yet-unclaimed cards. Most cards at the end of the deck wins.

item.description:
In this third game in Lookout's Zavandor fantasy setting, it's all about dwarves. And mining. And gemstones. And other enhancements for the mines that need to get developed further during the game to have full effect.

4 different gems are the currencies in this game. However, when collecting income you draw cards from 4 different mines (card stacks) with each having its own distribution! The number of gems you earn depends on the upgrade level of your dwarves. Gems are used to either win new objects for their mine through simultaneous 4-way auctions, or to enhance their mines, objects, and victory point count. Another innovative part is that each object has to be upgraded to fully use its benefits, e.g. a level 1 dwarf only gives you 1 income per round, some level 3 dwarves give you 3 income.

On the King's way through the mountain, the requirements for upgrading some special cards always change, and only the player who wins the sapphire auction knows where the next turn will lead to. There are shorter and longer paths to the Coronation Chamber, where the game ends. The game lasts between 10 to 12 rounds.

name.value: Objective: Kiev (The Advance of Army Group South: June-August, 1941)

item.description:
The Advance of Army Group South:
June - August, 1941

When the Germans launched Operation Barbarossa on 22 June 1941, they faced both their greatest expanse of territory to capture and the greatest concentration of Soviet armor south of the Pripet marsh in Ukraine. Army Group South launched its multi-national forces (including Rumanians, Hungarians and Italians) with their principal target defined – Objective: Kiev.

Facing them was the Red Army weakened from the recent purges of its officers by Stalin. Still, the Soviets put together a strong counter-attack early in the campaign, but their advantages in numbers of tanks committed could not overcome the German's superiority of skill when employing their veteran panzer units. The Axis forces advanced eastward to the Dnieper River and south toward Odessa, but as the front kept expanding, forces were spread thinner to cover the front line.

Objective: Kiev is a new historical board game from renowned game designer Frank Chadwick, iterating the classic Battle for Moscow game system used in The Arduous Beginning, combining ease of learning and design elegance with the kind of dramatic gameplay that Frank has long been famous for. Featuring countless opportunities and variations, Objective: Kiev presents an endlessly fascinating series of puzzles and is a game that you're going to want to play again and again.

Published in C3i magazine #26.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1 - 2 weeks
Hex: 31 miles / 50 kilometers
Units: Corps to Army

Game Inventory:
One 11 x 17" full color map
One dual-side printed countersheet (40 1/2" game counters - 28)
One 6-page Objective Kiev foldout rules booklet
One single-side printed Play Aid card

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium-Low
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15

item.description:
He Who Dies with the Most Loot
Probably Ran into the Dragon

Dungeons are for looting. Every good adventurer knows that. Unfortunately, there are those pesky monsters to take care of before the real work can begin – counting all the loot.

Loot and Scoot is a fast-playing game of dungeons, dragons and running faster than the hirelings when the going gets too tough. Two to four players construct dungeons, recruit adventuring groups, and loot the most treasure before the Dungeon Boss is found... and killed.

Money is earned by looting dungeon rooms. Those valuable coins are then used to buy more retainers, upgrade your training facilities, recruit more adventurers (from four different classes), and train Squires into Knights (or Level 1 Priests into Level 2 Bishops, you get the idea). In the end, the player who successfully looted the most difficult dungeon rooms is the winner and gets to gloat over their friends back at the Inn.

Game Data:
Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 4 on a 9 scale
Scale: Individual heroes vs. individual or groups of monsters

Game Components:
• One illustrated, color 2-page Rules sheet
• 80 color, die-cut 5/8" square playing pieces
• 56 color, die-cut 5/8" round game makers
• 4 Dungeon player mats

link.value: Loot and Scoot Expansion Kit #1: Loot Harder

item.description:
From GMT's web site:

The Fast Action Battle (FAB) games, designed by Rick Young (Europe Engulfed, Asia Engulfed, and FAB: The Bulge), takes you to the Allied invasion of Sicily for volume II of the series.

As the Allied player, you will choose your invasion beaches after seeing where the Axis player has deployed his units. Do you choose Montgomery’s historical ‘Husky’ plan, Patton’s alternate plan, or a hybrid plan of your own?

In this game you will find a few new unit and asset types, and also new challenges for both sides. For the attacker, the challenge is the tough Sicilian terrain; and for the defenders, it’s the worsening Italian morale.

Each victory area and functioning port that the Allies secure adds a ‘Fading Italian Morale’ Event Chit into the selection cup, and as each of those are drawn, worsening effects on Italian units are felt along the entire front.

If one side has not secured an automatic victory by the end of turn 9, the Axis player receives bonuses, both for German units that have exited off the island through Messina and also for areas on Sicily that are still Axis-controlled, so there is pressure on both sides to fight for every area.

Event Chits include:


 Replacements
 Fading Italian Morale,
 the Patton Soldier Slap, and
 flanking battalion-sized invasions.

item.description:
(from GMT's website:)

No Retreat: The Russian Front is a new deluxe edition of the two-player Victory Point Games 2008 CSR Award Nominee wargame that retells the story of the titanic struggle between the invading armies of Nazi Germany versus Communist Russia during WW2 at a player-friendly and manageable level of scope and difficulty. This edition combines both the original game and its two extensions (Na Berlin! and No Surrender!) using deluxe components of “Twilight Struggle Deluxe Edition” quality. With only 40 Army/Front sized counters for the Tournament game, and 70 for the whole campaign, and with very low stacking, it’s a quick-playing yet realistic affair that favours the strategic and offensive-minded player.

Each turn is alight with intriguing on-board challenges plus the surprise of card hand Events as players vie to win in one of three different ways.

In a skillfully blended collation of classic hex-based wargaming and modern card-driven simulations, No Retreat: The Russian Front stays truly story-centric, providing the proper feel of sweeping maneuvers, exploitation and encirclements across the vast steppes and forests of Russia. With a simple-yet-innovative economic model, players will also feel the growing might and sophistication of the Russian’s Red Army, and the degradation of the once-invincible German Wehrmacht, over the epic four year sweep of time that this merciless campaign was fought.

Neither side can afford the disgrace of yielding an inch of ground to their hated foe, so your orders are: “No Retreat!”

Components:

 One Standard size mounted map
 Two Counter Sheets
 One deck of 55 Playing Cards
 Rule booklet
 Scenario booklet
 Player Aid Cards
 Two 6-sided dice (1 black and 1 white)




TIME SCALE: 2 months per turn
MAP SCALE: 100km / 60 miles per hex
UNIT SCALE: Armies and Fronts
NUMBER OF PLAYERS: 2

DESIGNER: Carl Paradis
DEVELOPER: Alan Emrich & Carl Paradis
COUNTER ART: Mark Simonitch & Carl Paradis
MAP ART: Mark Simonitch

item.description:
Poznajemy Kolory is a children's game for 2-4 players, Ages 4 - 8.

This game is a child's introduction to colors.

The game is designed to encourage children to compare and logical thinking.

Players in this game have only one task - they have to identified as soon as possible the colors thrown a pair of colorful dice and associate them with the colors of cardboards on the table, spread cocks. Who will recognize the appropriate colors on the rooster, that puts him on his chip. Very simple rules of the game makes it fun for young and older children and even adults. The youngest learn the recognition and naming colors.

Talk in Text
The Code Breaking Puzzle Game

Just how well do you know your mobile phone? Talk in Text is a fabulous new code-breaking puzzle game, where players race to decode text message teasers using a numeric keypad. Includes 160 puzzles and four "phones" to help players decipher the codes! For up to 4 players.

(from Mindware.com)

PentaKribb is billed as "Boardless Cribbage". Instead of the traditional board, players are provided a scoring sheet to post their hands and scores. Players are not dealt their own, individual hands. Instead, the dealer turns a single card face up. The players enter that card onto their own score sheet, placing it into the square of their choice in a 4 x 5 grid. This is repeated until all 20 spaces are filled in. The dealer then turns over a single cut card. The result is 5 hands of 5 cards for each player. The scores are added up for all the hands. This is repeated for five deals. The highest score at the end of the five deals wins the game.

From published rules on the box.

From the inside of the box of "Leapin' Lemurs" Peanut Butter & Chocolate cereal.

When Ring-tailed Lemurs get mad at each other, sometimes they wipe their scent all over their tails and have a sort of stinky sword fight with them. Seeing as you don't have a tail, this is an easier (and less smelly!) way to have a Stink Fight!

Object: To get your 2 tokens from the START row at the bottom of the board into 2 white spaces in the FINISH row, while avoiding other players or the black 'Aw Stink!' squares.

Components:
7 x 13 board
6 player tokens
Rules
Player provided die

3singes (3monkeys) is a unique party game, as it handicaps the players. It is based on the chinese three monkeys of wisdom.

One player is blind but knows all (with 3 cards) and must tell the mute player how to mime the phrase to the deaf, without saying to the mute what he is miming, but HOW to do it, and the blind cannot see if the mute mime it correctly.

The deaf players (having iPods or similar things) don't hear what the blind is saying, so they must try to understand the blind's message according to the mute's mimes. If a blind player hears a correct element, he indicates the mute a deaf got a good answer and points are scored.

item.description:
This game available only in Hungarian yet.
The "quizmaster" read a rarely use word from a card, and the players are to define it. 
The fun of this game is, that usually nobody ever heard these words before. 
Being everybody ready, the quizmaster collect the answers, and together with correct answer, read it. The players then vote to one, he thinks is the correct.

item.description:
The first player who succeeds travelling around the gameboard, and makes it "home" with all of his four pieces - and, finally beats his last piece off the board, wins the game.
The players have different colored pieces, and during gameplay they use a normal D6-dice, and a special Globe-dice/Star-dice, which gives special move-rights.
The players are able to "beat each other home" when jumping to the same field as an opponent.
The game continues until the last man is alone onboard.
This simple game immediately gives rise to many intrigues and emotional discussions - Believe me :)

name.value: Pastora or the Shepherdess of the Pyrenees: A diverting game calculated to kill care and enliven the dreary hours of winter

item.description:
This Game, like many others of a similar nature, will shew the variety and innocent amusement that may be derived from a Pack of Cards; were the admirers of them as solicitous to acquire the useful lessons with which they are fraught, as they are to appropriate them to the destruction of each other's fortune, they would soon take precedence of every invention for the exercise of the mind.

Pastora or the Shepherdess of the Pyrenees, is represented in the centre of the plate which accompanies the Rules. In the corners representations of playing cards - King of Hearts, Queen of Spades, Jack of Clubs, 10 of Diamonds.

Equipment required: pack of playing cards.

The game is described as 'designed to allure the minds of youth to an acquaintance with the wonders of nature'. The playing surface has 37 playing spaces each with an animal. The game is played with a teetotum marked on eight sides. The animals featured include the otter, armadillo, beaver, sheep, rat, lynx, monkey and fox. The end of the game is marked by the lion. The game comes with a booklet which describes the animals.

Two or three persons may amuse themselves with this agreeable pastime; and if a double set of counters and pyramids are purchased, six persons may play at it.
